awd_titl_txt: Digital Media and Parent/Child Engagement Resources to Increase Preschool Computational Thinking
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will capitalize on the power of story to teach foundational computational thinking (CT) concepts through the creation of animated and live-action videos, paired with joint media engagement activities, for preschool children and their parents. Exposure at a young age to CT is critical for preparing all students to engage with the technologies that have become central to nearly every occupation. But despite this recognized need, there are few, if any, resources that (1) introduce CT to young children; (2) define the scope of what should be taught; and (3) provide evidence-based research on effective strategies for bringing CT to a preschool audience. To meet these needs, WGBH and Education Development Center/Center for Children and Technology (EDC/CCT) will utilize an iterative research and design process to create animated and live-action videos paired with joint media engagement activities for parents and preschool children, titled "Monkeying Around".  Animated videos will model for children how to direct their curiosity into a focused exploration of the problem-solving process. Live-action videos will feature real kids and their parents and will further illustrate how helpful CT can be for problem solving. With their distinctive visual humor and captivating storytelling, the videos will be designed to entice parents to watch alongside their children. This is important since parents will play an important role in guiding them in explorations that support their CT learning. To further promote joint media engagement, hands-on activities will accompany the videos. Following the creation of these resources, an experimental impact study will be conducted to capture evidence as to if and how these resources encourage the development of young children's computational thinking, and to assess parents' comfort and interest in the subject. Concurrent with this design-based research process, the project will build on the infrastructure of state systems of early education and care (which have been awarded Race to the Top grants) and local public television stations to design and develop an outreach initiative to reach parents.  Additional partners--National Center for Women & Information Technology, Code in Schools, and code.org (all of whom are all dedicated to promoting CT)--will further help bring this work to a national audience. 

Can parent/child engagement with digital media and hands-on activities improve children's early learning of computational thinking? To answer this question, WGBH and EDC/CCT are collaborating on a design-based research process with children and their parents to create  Monkeying Around successive interactions. The overarching goal of this mixed-methods research effort is to generate evidence that supports the development of recommendations around the curricular, instructional, and contextual factors that support or impede children's acquisition of CT as a result of digital media viewing and hands-on engagement. Moving through cycles of implementation, observation, analysis, and revision over the course of three years, EDC/CCT researchers will work closely with families and WGBH's development team to determine how children learn the fundamentals of CT, how certain learning tasks can demonstrate what children understand, how to stimulate interest in hands-on activities, and the necessary scaffolds to support parental involvement in the development of children's CT. Each phase of the research will provide rich feedback to inform the next cycle of content development and will include: Phase 1: the formulation of three learning blueprints (for algorithmic thinking, sequencing, and patterns); Phase 2: the development of a cohesive set of learning tasks to provide evidence of student learning, as well as the production of a prototype of the digital media and parent/child engagement resources (algorithmic thinking); Phase 3-Part A: pilot research on the prototype, revisions, production of two additional prototypes (sequencing and patterns); Phase 3-Part B: pilot research on the three prototypes and revisions; and Phase 4: production of 27 animated and live-action videos and 18 parent/child engagement activities and a study of their impact. Through this process, the project team will build broader knowledge about how to design developmentally appropriate resources promoting CT for preschool children and will generate data on how to stimulate interest in hands-on activities and the necessary scaffolds to support parental involvement in the development of children's CT. The entire project represents an enormous opportunity for WGBH and for the informal STEM media field to learn more about how media can facilitate informal CT learning in the preschool years and ways to broaden participation by building parents' capacity to support STEM learning.  This project is funded by the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program, which seeks to advance new approaches to, and evidence-based understanding of, the design and development of STEM learning in informal environments. This includes providing multiple pathways for broadening access to and engagement in STEM learning experiences, advancing innovative research on and assessment of STEM learning in informal environments, and developing understandings of deeper learning by participants.

por.por_cntn:
Digital Media and Parent/Child Engagement Resources to Increase Preschool Computational Thinking was designed to yield new understanding of how young children can engage with computational thinking (CT) in non-programming contexts and the role parents can play in supporting children's CT learning via joint media engagement.

Guided by Content Director Dr. Marina Bers, a leader in the field of preschool CT, developers from GBH and researchers from EDC began the project by creating a learning blueprint that drew from the literature to identify six CT core ideas for 4- and 5-year-old children. We fully articulated three of these ideas (algorithmic thinking, debugging, and design process), including a delineation of how they progress across early childhood, descriptions of tasks that address their goals, ways to vary task difficulty, and scaffolding strategies. This blueprint was the foundational document for iterative research and development of media, consisting of Aha! Island animated stories hosted by an entertaining cast characters living in an island community, along with related hands-on activities, which gave parents the background they need to turn everyday situations - like setting the table - into an opportunity to apply CT.

An impact study, using a randomized controlled trial conducted by EDC of a sample of 108 ethnically diverse families (from lower socio-economic communities in New York, Rhode Island, and Boston), demonstrated evidence of promise of the Aha! Island resources. Parents reported that the videos and hands-on activities gave them ideas about how to engage with their children and support CT learning. A large majority of parents thought that their children enjoyed the videos (91%) and the hands-on activities (95%), said they would continue watching the videos with their children after the study was over (89%), and reported that the videos and hands-on activities made their child excited about solving problems (83% videos and 87% hands-on activities) and helped them solve problems in more organized ways (80% videos and 91% hands-on activities). In interviews with a sub-set of these parents, most parents reported sitting with their child to watch and discuss the CT promoted in the videos. After watching the videos and doing the hands-on activities, parents reported that their children were more independent, persistent, and systematic in the ways they approached things than prior to engaging in the resources. Parents also reported that their children repeated the CT language that was presented in the videos. Observational data of parents and children supported these results; researchers found that videos fostered rich caregiver-child interactions (including asking questions, making comments, and looking and smiling at each other), and that children exhibited high levels of plot comprehension and attention to CT content during viewing.

A major component of this project was the development of community engagement models. GBH partnered with the BUILD Initiative, public broadcasters, and other state systems in Maryland and Mississippi to create two engagement models: a "Learning Party Model" (multi-session, interactive, parent/child parties that promote parents' education as well as young children's development of school readiness skills) and a "Library Model" (a series of in-person sessions that include video viewing, opportunities for directed child play, hands-on activities, and read-alouds). A summative evaluation conducted by Concord Evaluation Group found that educators liked the program because it was easy to use; the videos held children's attention (providing both entertainment as well as education); and families enjoyed the experience of working with new families and spending quality time with their children. Several educators reported that, although the content was aimed at supporting children's learning, they observed that the resources were extremely educational for parents, as well.

Another major component of this work was creation of learning tasks. Developed by EDC, they were designed to advance our understanding of how children's early learning of CT can be measured and assessed. This research yielded a great deal of insight into how young children's CT can be nurtured through joint-media engagement between parents and children. More specifically, we now have a much better understanding of how to: promote the use of CT core ideas by helping children verbalize ordered processes; encourage children to be flexible in their thinking and find different ways to solve problems; support parents in helping their children break down problems, including asking open-ended questions to encourage new thinking; slow down the pace of activities to allow for productive struggle; and use strategies that promote deep processing, giving children time to notice problems.

Based in large part on the success of this project, GBH recently received funding from the Department of Education Ready To Learn grant to create a PBS KIDS multimedia initiative (slated to premiere in February 2023) that uses television, digital games, podcasts, and resources for educators and caregivers to capitalize on the power of appealing characters and relatable storylines to teach foundational computational thinking ideas to children ages 3-5.
